sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Kyrgyzstan is a landlocked country in Central Asia, known for its dramatic mountain landscapes, nomadic heritage, and strong cultural traditions rooted in Central Asian history.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Bishkek is the capital and largest city of Kyrgyzstan. It serves as the countryâ€™s political, economic, and cultural center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Kyrgyzstan is the Kyrgyzstani som (KGS).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official languages are Kyrgyz and Russian. Kyrgyz is the state language, while Russian is widely used in business and government.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Kyrgyz cuisine is heavily influenced by nomadic traditions, featuring meat-based dishes such as beshbarmak, manty, and laghman.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Kyrgyzstan is dominated by the Tian Shan mountain range, with over 90% of its territory covered by mountains. It has cold winters and mild to warm summers depending on altitude.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Kyrgyz culture emphasizes hospitality, respect for elders, and nomadic traditions. Yurts, horse culture, and epic storytelling such as the Epic of Manas are central cultural elements.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Popular tourist attractions include Issyk-Kul Lake, Ala Archa National Park, Song-Kul Lake, and traditional yurt stays.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: The Epic of Manas, a traditional Kyrgyz poem, is one of the longest epic poems in the world.

history.event: Early Kyrgyz tribes established a powerful khaganate in Central Asia.
The region came under the control of the Mongol Empire.
Kyrgyz territories were gradually incorporated into the Russian Empire.
Kyrgyzstan became the Kyrgyz Soviet Socialist Republic within the USSR.
Kyrgyzstan declared independence following the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
The Tulip Revolution led to political reforms and leadership change.
